title: 3HV - Stercollectie Engels Unit 4 money - grammar overview with exercises
description: money - grammar overview and exercises both from Stercollectie and from other websites

items.content:
In this section, you will find information about adjectives, adverbs, comparatives and superlatives.

  • Adjectives and adverbs
  • Comparatives of adjectives
  • Superlatives of adjectives
  • Comparatives and superlatives of adverbs

What are adjectives?


Adjectives are words that tell us something about a noun (zelfst. nw), pronoun (pers. vnw.), impression or situation.

What do adjectives modify (change)?
Adjectives can modify nouns or pronouns/names.

person thing
Mandy is a careful girl This is a nice car
Mandy is careful The car is nice
She is careful It is nice


Where do adjectives go?
An adjective can be put before the noun. Then it is an attribute (eigenschap).

person thing
Mandy is a careful girl This is a nice car

An adjective can be put after the verb to be (is).
Then it is part of the predicate (gezegde).

person thing
The girl is careful This car is nice


Adjectives can also be used after the following verbs:
appear to, become, feel, get, go, keep, turn, look, like, smell, sound, taste and other verbs of experience.

Examples:

  • The steak smells fantastic
  • She turned red
  • He got excited
  • It tastes awful

What are adverbs?


Adverbs tell us in what way someone does something.
Adverbs can modify verbs (here: drive), adjectives or other adverbs.

adjective adverb
Mandy is a careful girl Mandy drives carefully
She is very careful She drives carefully

Explanation:
Mandy is a careful driver.
This sentence is about Mandy, the driver, so use the adjective.

Mandy drives carefully.
This sentence is about her way of driving, so use the adverb

An adverb answers the question: how?


Form of the adverb: adjective + -ly

adjective adverb
dangerous dangerously
careful carefully
nice nicely
horrible horribly
easy easily
electronic electronically

Adverbs formed from adjectives ending -y, pronounced like Dutch 'ie'
If the adjective ends in -y, change the final -y to -i. Then add -ly:
happy - happily
but:
shy - shyly (the 'y' in 'shy' does not sound like Dutch 'ie'.)

Adverbs formed from adjectives ending in -le
If the adjective ends in -le, drop the -e, and replace it with -y:
terrible - terribly

Adverbs formed from adjectives ending in -e
If the adjective ends in -e, then add -ly:
safe - safely

NB: Not all words ending in -ly are adverbs:

  • adjectives, ending in -ly: friendly, silly, lonely, ugly
  • nouns, ending in -ly: ally, bully, Italy, melancholy
  • verbs, ending in -ly: apply, rely, supply

NB 2: There is no separate adverb for an adjective already ending in -ly.

Irregular forms
There are some irregular forms, where the adverb differs from the adjective.

Other irregular forms show no difference between the adjective and the adverb.

adjective aaadverb
good well
fast fast
hard hard

heading.content: extra exercises on adjectives and adverbs

items.content:
Comparative is the grammar name used when comparing two things.


The two basic ways to compare are using as ... as or than.


She's twice as old as her sister.
I'm almost as good in maths as in science.
Russian is not quite as difficult as Chinese.

It's much colder today than it was yesterday.
This grammar topic is easier than most others.
I find science more difficult than mathematics.

Comparisons with as ... as versus comparisons with than:
When comparing with as ... as, the adjective does not change.
When comparing with than, however, some changes are necessary.

Comparing with than : Look at the number of syllables the adjective has:

Adjectives of one syllable:
1. syllable adjectives: add to the adjective

My sister is much taller than me.
It's colder today than it was yesterday.

Note: If the word ends: consonant-vowel-consonant, then the last consonant is usually doubled in the comparative.
big - bigger, fat - fatter, hot - hotter

Adjectives of two syllables ending in -y:
2. syllable adjectives ending in -y: change the -y to -ier

She's looking happier today.
This grammar topic is easier than the last one.
Why is everyone else luckier than me?

Other adjectives with two or more syllables:


Other 2-syllable adjectives: use more with the unchanged adjective

The shops are always more crowded just before Christmas.
Is there anything more boring than reading about grammar?
My sister is more careful with her writing than I am with mine.

Exceptions
The comparative of some shorter 2-syllable adjectives can be formed with -er.

  • simple - simpler
  • clever - cleverer
  • narrow - narrower

To be sure which comparative method to use, you will need to consult a good dictionary.

Adjectives with three syllables or more:
Adjectives with 3 or more syllables: use more and unchanged adjective

Russian grammar is more difficult than English grammar.
My sister is much more intelligent than me.
I find maths lessons more enjoyable than science lessons.

content.body:
Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
easy / happy / heavy / hot / important

  • The weather in Equatorial Africa is than the weather in Europe.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
easy / expensive / happy / hot / quick

good / happy / hot / tall / young

bad / happy / hot / quick / tall

  • In most schools a 5 is a grade than an 10.

easy / good / happy / hot / tall

  • A camel is not as as a giraffe.

easy / heavy / hot / important / young

  • She's 10 minutes than her twin sister.

Choose from:
delicious / expensive / important / large / quick

  • Is it to be rich or to be popular?

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
boring / happy / heavy / hot / quick

  • An elephant is than a mouse, but much lighter than a blue whale.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
boring / happy / heavy / hot / quick

  • My sister can run twice as as me.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
expensive / happy / heavy / hot / large

  • Notebook computers are usually than desktop computers.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
happy / crowded / easy / heavy / young

  • The cafeteria is today than it was yesterday.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
crowded / delicious / happy / heavy / important

  • English food is not as as Korean food.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
crowded / delicious / easy / expensive / rich

  • My friend is than me and lives in large house.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
crowded / delicious / happy / large / tall

  • She does not seem as now as before she was married.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the comparative form.
Choose from:
expensive / hot / tall / boring / young

  • This grammar quiz was even than usual.

items.content:
In the superlative you talk about one thing only and how it is the best, worst, etc.
You do not compare two things. The following guidelines apply to the superlative:

Adjectives with one syllable:
1-syllable adjectives: add -estto the adjective (plus )

My sister is the tallestin our family.
Yesterday was the coldest day of the year so far.

Note: If the word ends: consonant-vowel-consonant, then the last consonant is usually doubled in the superlative.
big - biggest, fat - fattest, hot - hottest

Adjectives of two syllables ending in -y:
2-syllable adjectives ending in -y: change the -y to -iest(plus the)

The richest people are not always the happiest
Which do you think is the easiest language to learn?
She's the luckiest person I know.

Other adjectives with two syllables:
Other 2-syllable adjectives: use the most with the unchanged adjective

The most boringthing about ESL class is doing grammar exercises.
My sister is the most careful person I know.

Exceptions
The superlative of some shorter 2-syllable adjectives can be formed with -est.

  • simple - simplest
  • clever - cleverest
  • narrow - narrowest

To be sure which comparative method to use, you will need to consult a good dictionary.

Adjectives of three syllables or more:
Adjectives with 3 or more syllables: use the most with the unchanged adjective

Some people think that Russian is language.
Albert Einstein was the person in history.
My most enjoyable class is English.

Irregular forms
Following are two common irregular comparative/superlative forms:

good - better - the best
bad - worse - the worst

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

Choose from:

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

  • Yesterday it was 29°C, the day of the year so far.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the superlative form.

Choose from:

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

  • For some students mathematics is the subject they take.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the superlative form.

Choose from:

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the superlative form.

Choose from:

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / exciting / expensive / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

  • Lord of the Rings was the film I have ever seen.

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the superlative form.

Choose from:

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy / enjoyable / funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

  • We had a great holiday. In fact, I think it was the I have ever had.

bad / comfortable / difficult / easy funny / good / high / hot / important / large / sad / useful / young

Choose the most probable adjective and put it in the superlative form.

heading.content: extra exercises on comparative and superlative adjectives

items.content:
Adverbs of one syllable:

comparative: + er superlative: the ...+ est
I can run faster than you. I can run the fastest in my class.
She works harder than me. She works the hardest of all students.

​
Longer adverbs: use more / the most

She ran more quickly than me. / Of all the students she ran the most quickly.

Informal forms of adverbs
In informal English we often hear the adjectival comparative/superlative.

For example with quickly:

Informal formal
She ran quicker than me. She ran more quickly.
She ran more quickly. She ran the most quickly.


Formal forms of of the pronouns with comparisons

Many educated English speakers add prefer to use the subject form (onderwerp) rather than the object form (meewerkend voorwerp) ,especially in formal situations.


They say, for example:

She ran more quickly than I did. (Not: She ran quicker than me).

content.body:
Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

Example:

He is singing ................. than the other singers. (loudly)

He is singing more loudly than the other singers.

  • He arrived than expected. (early)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • We walked than the rest of the people. (slowly)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • They called us in the afternoon. (late)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • My mother and my sister talked than the other guests. (loudly)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • He hit his arm than before. (hard)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • The Spanish athlete ran than the other runners. (fast)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • Jim threw the ball than Peter. (far)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • We answered all the questions than the other students. (well)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • Our new teacher explains the exercises than our old teacher. (badly)

Fill in the blank with the correct comparative form of the adverb.

  • The new mechanic checked the car more than the old mechanic. (thoroughly).

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

Example:

Tom sang more loudly (more loudly / the most loudly) than the other kids.

  • I visit my parents than my brothers do. (more often/the most often)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • He thinks he always knows . (better/best)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • Out of all my siblings, I visit my parents . (more often/the most often)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • David did than he thought he would do on his test. (worse/the worst)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • I did out of all the students on my test. (worse/the worst)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • Out of all the students, Frank studied , but got the best grade. (less/the least)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • We argued than I thought we would. (longer/the longest)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • My sisters laughed out of the whole audience. (louder/the loudest)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • The two guys who enjoyed the game were Tom and Robert. (more/most)

Fill in the blank with either the comparative form or superlative form of each adverb.

  • George drives than his brother. (more recklessly/the most recklessly)

heading.content: extra exercises on comparative and superlative adverbs

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

wonderful - city - world. - most - York - the - New - the - is - in

values.value: New York is the most wonderful city in the world.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

beautiful - I - girl - ever - the - met. - have - most - is - Jenny

values.value: Jenny is the most beautiful girl I have ever met.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

in - is - class. - his - the - pupil - Jack - brightest

values.value: Jack is the brightest pupil in his class.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

isn't - her - clever - as - brother. - as - Mary

values.value: Mary isn't as clever as her brother.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

the - is - worst - This - bought. - ever - you - dress - have

values.value: This is the worst dress you have ever bought.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

house - A - a - usually - than - flat. - is - bigger

values.value: A house is usually bigger than a flat.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

comfortable - Your - car. - more - is - than - my - car

values.value: Your car is more comfortable than my car.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

jet - is - faster - truck. - a - than - A

values.value: A jet is faster than a truck.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

witch - than - fairy. - a - is - uglier - A

values.value: A witch is uglier than a fairy.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

get - for - for - worse. - better - married - They - or

values.value: They get married for better or for worse.

content.body:
Build a sentence with the words:

eaten. - is - best - ever - cake - This - I've - the

values.value: This is the best cake I've ever eaten.

content.body:
Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • She's than her husband. (young)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • This is the case in the shop. (strong)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • This new TV programme is much than the old one. (funny)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • You're the person here. (friendly)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • The traffic is than it was last year. (noisy)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • My office is than Helen's. (near)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • She's the student in the group. (intelligent)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • Ms Davies is a teacher than Mr Andrews. (good)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • These people are the in the country. (poor)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • It's the programme on television. (boring)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • This is the hotel in town. (cheap)

Complete the sentences with either a comparative or a superlative. Use the word in (parentheses).

  • The train is than the bus. (expensive)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Our father arrived home than the rest of the family. (late)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • My sister sang than Amanda did. (beautifully)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Your husband, Ken, writes of all. (well)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Mrs. Henderson speaks than Mrs. Alarcon. (clearly)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Mother prepares turkey than father does. (well)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Alexander and Peter work of all the boys. (hard)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • He checked his answers than she did. (carefully)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Angelica speaks Spanish of all the students. (correctly)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • Percy talks than Jennifer. (frequently)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • She danced of all. (gracefully)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • This math test was than the last one. (hard)

Complete each sentence with the correct form of the adverb in (parantheses).

  • I did my homework than my brother. (fast)
